Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Equivariant Gromov-Witten Theory and Symplectic Vortices; July 2009, Luminy, France
Award.AbstractNarration: Abstract<br/><br/>Award: DMS-0835558<br/>Principal Investigator: Christopher Woodward<br/><br/>Algebraic geometry, symplectic geometry and low-dimensional<br/>topology have been revolutionized in recent years by the<br/>introduction of holomorphic curve techniques. This workshop, to<br/>be held July 6-10, 2009, at the CIRM (Luminy) conference center,<br/>concerns equivariant generalizations of invariants defined by<br/>holomorphic curves. In Gromov-Witten theory, equivariant<br/>invariants have been extensively studied by Givental and others,<br/>in the sense of integrals of equivariant cohomology classes over<br/>moduli spaces of stable maps. The focus of the workshop will be<br/>on the following more sophisticated version of equivariant<br/>Gromov-Witten theory: the study of moduli spaces of maps to the<br/>stack-theoretic quotient of, say, a smooth projective variety by<br/>a reductive group. By definition, such a map consists of a<br/>holomorphic principal bundle, together with a section of the<br/>associated bundle. From the symplectic point of view, suitable<br/>moduli spaces of such pairs are known as moduli spaces of {\em<br/>symplectic vortices}. The workshop is organized around this<br/>specific direction, with an aim to bring together researchers in<br/>algebraic and symplectic geometry who have had no previous<br/>interaction. On the other hand, the workshop will promote<br/>discussion of the interaction of holomorphic maps, gauge theory,<br/>and group actions more broadly. Applications of the theory are<br/>expected for instance, to the relation between Gromov-Witten<br/>theories of different varieties, and to the relation between the<br/>gauge-theoretic invariants such as Floer-Donaldson invariants and<br/>their symplectic analogs.<br/><br/>We propose a workshop which will bring together gauge theory and<br/>holomorphic curves. Gauge theory is the study of local symmetry<br/>in mathematics and physics; the most famous example is<br/>electromagnetism. Holomorphic curve techniques aim, in algebraic<br/>geometry, to understand spaces by understanding the certain<br/>classes of curves in them, or in symplectic geometry, to<br/>understand the periodic orbits of dynamical systems. Symmetry of<br/>the target varieties may be used as a computational tool, and<br/>also combined with holomorphic curves to define new invariants.<br/>The workshop will focus on recent developments and emerging<br/>applications to algebraic geometry, symplectic geometry, and<br/>low-dimensional topology. The workshop will benefit a number of<br/>graduate students and postdoctoral fellows working in this area<br/>who have had little interaction with other groups working on<br/>related problems.<br/><br/>The conference web-page controlled by the organizers is<br/>www.math.rutgers.edu/~ctw/Luminy, while that controlled by the<br/>conference center CIRM is<br/>www.cirm.univ-mrs.fr/web.ang/liste_rencontre/Rencontres2009/Renc346/Renc346.html.<br/><br/>

Institution.Name: Rutgers University New Brunswick
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY
